tit.cmt: 不必要なスペースを削除
他のファイルにあわせてManorをつけました。

sen.j: 鹿子木荘（かのこぎのしょう・かなこぎのしょう）は、平安時代～室町時代にかけて肥後国にあった荘園。
sen.e: Kanokogi-no-sho/ Kanakogi-no-sho was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) existed in Higo Province during the Heian and Muromachi Periods.
Kanokogi-no-sho/Kanakogi-no-sho was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) that existed in Higo Province during the Heian and Muromachi Periods.
sen.cmt: 不必要なスペースを削除「that」を補足
sen.e: Kanokogi-no-sho/Kanakogi-no-sho was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) that existed in Higo Province during the Heian and Muromachi Periods.
It was an estate of To-ji Temple.
It was an estate of To-ji Temple.
It was an estate of To-ji Temple.
Akita Country, Higo Province.
Akita District, Higo Province
Akita District, Higo Province

sen.j: 現在の熊本県熊本市北部と北部町と植木町と合志市の一部。
sen.e: It extended from the north part of present Kumamoto City to Hokubu-machi Town of Kumamoto City, Ueki-machi Town of Kamoto-gun, and a part of Koshi City.
It covered the north part of modern-day Kumamoto City, Hokubu-machi Town of Kumamoto City, Ueki-machi Town of Kamoto-gun and part of Koshi City in Kumamoto Prefecture.
It covered the north part of modern-day Kumamoto City, Hokubu-machi Town of Kumamoto City, Ueki-machi Town of Kamoto-gun and part of Koshi City in Kumamoto Prefecture.
Unknown

Origin

sen.j: 沙弥寿妙が開発し、孫の鹿子木高方が応徳3年に大宰大弐藤原実政に寄進、実政失脚後は藤原公実が伝領し、外孫藤原隆通が勝功徳院に寄進、次いで仁和寺が本家とされた。
sen.e: It is said that Shami Jumyo developed it and his grandson Takakata KANOKOGI/KANAKOGI (鹿子木高方) donated it to dazai daini (senior assistant governor-general of Government Headquarters in Kyushu) FUJIWARA no Sanemasa in 1086, and after Sanemasa's downfall, FUJIWARA no Kinzane succeeded him to the manor, but later his grandson FUJIWARA no Takamichi (a son of Kinzane's daughter) donated it to Shokudoku-in Temple, and subsequently Ninna-ji Temple became its head family.
sen.cmt: 鹿子木高方→Takakata KANOKOGI/KANAKOGI (鹿子木高方) [正式な読み方が不明です]
sen.e: It is thought that the manor was developed by Shami Jumyo before being donated by his grandson Takakata KANOKOGI/KANAKOGI (鹿子木高方) to dazai daini (senior assistant governor-general of Government Headquarters in Kyushu) FUJIWARA no Sanemasa in 1086, and after Sanemasa's downfall, was inherited by FUJIWARA no Kinzane, but his grandson FUJIWARA no Takamichi (a son of Kinzane's daughter) later donated it to Shokudoku-in Temple and subsequently Ninna-ji Temple took on the role of head family.

It is thought that the manor was developed by Shami Jumyo before being donated by his grandson Takakata KANOKOGI/KANAKOGI (鹿子木高方) to dazai daini (senior assistant governor-general of Government Headquarters in Kyushu) FUJIWARA no Sanemasa in 1086, and after Sanemasa's downfall, was inherited by FUJIWARA no Kinzane, but his grandson FUJIWARA no Takamichi (a son of Kinzane's daughter) later donated it to Shokudoku-in Temple and subsequently Ninna-ji Temple took on the role of head family.

sen.e: Ryoke (Lord of the Manor)

sen.j: 藤原氏(藤原実政→藤原公実→願西ら)→堀川源氏(源具美→源基具ら)→賀島入道ら
sen.e: The Fujiwara clan (FUJIWARA no Sanemasa→FUJIWARA no Kinzane→Gansei, etc.) →Horikawa-Genji (Minamoto clan) MINAMOTO no Tomomi →MINAMOTO no Mototomi, etc.) →Kajima Nyudo, etc.
The Fujiwara clan (FUJIWARA no Sanemasa → FUJIWARA no Kinzane → Gansei, etc.) → Horikawa-Genji (Minamoto clan) MINAMOTO no Tomomi → MINAMOTO no Mototomi, etc.) → Kajima Nyudo, etc.
The Fujiwara clan (FUJIWARA no Sanemasa → FUJIWARA no Kinzane → Gansei, etc.) → Horikawa-Genji (Minamoto clan) MINAMOTO no Tomomi → MINAMOTO no Mototomi, etc.) → Kajima Nyudo, etc.
Post of betto (chief administrator of the manor)

sen.cmt: 不必要な「Post of」を削除Title caseにしました
sen.e: Betto (Chief Administrator of the Manor)

sen.j: 鹿子木氏→菊池氏・大友氏
sen.e: The Kanokogi/ Kanakogi clan → the Kikuchi clan and Otomo clan.
The Kanokogi/Kanakogi clan → the Kikuchi clan and Otomo clan.
sen.cmt: 不必要なスペースを削除
sen.e: The Kanokogi/Kanakogi clan → the Kikuchi clan and Otomo clan.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に大友氏の子孫で地頭の詫摩氏の勢力が拡大し、室町時代に荘園としての実態は失われた。
sen.e: The condition as a shoen (manor) was practically lost in the Muromachi Period, as the Takuma clan, a descendent of the Otomo clan and jito (land steward appointed by the central military government to each of the estates (shoen) into which the countryside was divided), extended its control over the territory in the Kamakura Period.
sen.cmt: 地頭→jito (land steward appointed by the central military government to each of the estates (shoen) into which the countryside was divided) [http://encyclopedia2.thefreedicationary.com/jito]
sen.e: The area lost its status as a manor in the Muromachi period after the Takuma clan which had descended from the Kanokogi/Kanakogi clan and served as jito (manager and lord of manor) expanded its power during the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: 原文を反映するように再構成しました
sen.e: The area lost its status as a manor in the Muromachi period after the Takuma clan which had descended from the Kanokogi/Kanakogi clan and served as jito (manager and lord of manor) expanded its power during the Kamakura period.
